thread.title: What's on: Your guide to the best Sydney attractions from October 18
thread.title_full: What's on: Your guide to the best Sydney attractions from October 18

author: Nicole Elphick
title: What's on: Your guide to the best Sydney attractions from October 18
text:
Enjoy guilt-free retail therapy with the waste-reduction initiative Garage Sale Trail around Sydney on October 24. Photo: Supplied 
Sunday October 18 FOOD Sugar fiends can indulge at Good Food Month's Sweetfest. Visitors can pick up tempting treats from Brickfields, Kakawa, MakMak and more, or watch master classes from Instagram baking queen Katherine Sabbath and pastry chef Andrew Bowden. 9am-1pm and 2-6pm, Ambush Gallery, Central Park, 28 Broadway, Chippendale, $20, sydney.goodfoodmonth.com. 
COMMUNITY For Marrickville Festival, the multicultural suburb will bustle with more than 120 stalls selling local produce and handmade gifts. The performers range from indie pop act the Secret City to musical duo Betty & Oswald. 10am-5pm, Marrickville and Illawarra roads, Marrickville, free, marrickville.nsw.gov.au. 
The Doug Anthony All Stars perform at Glebe's Harold Park Hotel on October 21. Photo: Supplied 
MUSIC Hear the surf-rock riffs of Melbourne punks Going Swimming as they play a free gig featuring tunes from their debut album, Deadtime Stories . 4pm, Frankie's Pizza, 50 Hunter Street, city, free, facebook.com/goingswimmingau. 
Advertisement Monday October 19 COMEDY Fans of the ABC sitcom Sammy J and Randy in Ricketts Lane can catch the human-puppet duo (and tomorrow) at the the Just For Laughs comedy festival. 7pm, Sydney Opera House, $42.90, 9250 7777, sydneyoperahouse.com. 
Collection+: Christian Thompson at the Sherman Contemporary Art Collection brings together a number of the artist's photography, sculpture and video works. Photo: Supplied 
DRINK New drops of the amber fluid can be discovered at the Inner West is Best Craft Beer Party, a collaborative launch from six different brewers in the area and part of Sydney Craft Beer Week. 5-10pm, Empire Hotel, 103A Parramatta Road, Annandale, free, sydneycraftbeerweek.com. 
Tuesday October 20 TALK  People tend not to feel smarter after a trip to the pub, but global initiative Raising the Bar aims to change that. Academics take over 20 watering holes to deliver talks on topics from the colonial food history of Sydney to the impact of doping on the Tour de France.  6.30-7.30pm, various locations, free (bookings essential), rtbevent.com/sydney-tickets-talks. 
Indian festival Parramasala takes place in Parramatta. Photo: Isabella Lettini 
MUSIC English folk songwriter and Brit Award winner Laura Marling returns to Australia for the first time since her sold-out tour in 2013. On her latest album, Short Movie , she moves towards a more electric sound, with Spin calling the record "her most captivating yet". 8pm, Enmore Theatre, 118 Enmore Road, Newtown, $69.90, 132 849, ticketek.com.au.
Wednesday October 21 MUSIC  Giant Dwarf launch a new acoustic series, My Tunes , in which an Australian personality chooses a musician close to their heart to interview. In the inaugural edition, Triple J's Zan Rowe picks Something For Kate's Paul Dempsey to strum tunes and chat about his creative process.  8pm, Giant Dwarf, 199 Cleveland Street, Redfern, $35, giantdwarf.com.au. 
COMEDY  Paul McDermott, Tim Ferguson and Paul "Flacco" Livingston join forces for the revived Doug Anthony All Stars. Expect barbed witticisms as well as some new songs. 8pm, Harold Park Hotel, 70a Ross Street, Glebe, $30, moshtix.com.au .
Thursday October 22 MUSIC  Jazz musician Kamasi Washington has agilely crossed genres, appearing on albums from Flying Lotus, Lauryn Hill and Kendrick Lamar. Hear him play tracks from his ambitious and critically acclaimed triple album The Epic at a Soulfest side show.  7pm, The Basement, 29 Reiby Place, Circular Quay, $59, 1300 438 849, moshtix.com.au. 
STAGE  Ensemble Theatre stage the world premiere of Christopher Harley's Blood Bank (until November 22), a slow unravelling of secrets set in a chilly waiting room. The play started life as part of the Ensemble Stages Spring Reading in 2013, before making its way into the 2015 main season.  8.15pm, Ensemble Theatre, 78 McDougall Street, Kirribilli, $69, 9929 0644, ensemble.com.au .
Friday October 23 ART  Collection+: Christian Thompson (until December 12) brings together a number of the artist's photography, sculpture and video works that merge Aboriginal iconography with fashion-related imagery.  11am-5pm, Sherman Contemporary Art Foundation, 16-20 Goodhope Street, Paddington, free, 9331 1112, sherman-scaf.org.au. 
COMMUNITY  Colourful cultural celebration Parramasala (until October 25) kicks off with an opening night parade weaving its way from Parramatta Town Hall to Prince Alfred Square. See the bright Bollywood outfits and lively drummers as the procession marches along Church Street.  6-10.15pm, throughout Parramatta, free, parramasala.com .
Saturday October 24 MARKET  Enjoy some guilt-free retail therapy with the waste-reduction initiative Garage Sale Trail. Either organise your own sidewalk flea market or hunt down a treasure at the many rummage sales popping up around town.  Various times, throughout Sydney, free, garagesaletrail.com.au. 
FESTIVAL  Americana music fest Out on the Weekend has an excellent bill of country-leaning musos from Dawes and Kasey Chambers to supergroup Tex, Don and Charlie (comprising of Tex Perkins, Don Walker and Charlie Owen).  11.30am-10.30pm, Bella Vista Farm, corner Norwest Boulevard and Elizabeth MacArthur Drive, Bella Vista, $99, 1300 762 545, outontheweekend.com.au. 
Sunday October 25 TOUR  It's the final tour day of the year for Australia's oldest and longest-operating navigational lighthouse, Macquarie Lightstation. Learn about its historical significance and climb the 100 stairs to the top to take in the beautiful harbour views.  10am-4pm, Macquarie Lightstation, Old South Head Road, Vaucluse, $5 (bookings essential), 8969 2100, harbourtrust.gov.au. 
ART  Feast your eyes upon some stunning canvases at The Greats (until February 14), an exhibition of masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland. See more than 70 works from artists including Botticelli, Cezanne, Monet and Vermeer, with all but two of them appearing for the first time in Australia.  10am-5pm, Art Gallery of NSW, Art Gallery Road, The Domain, city, $22, 1800 679 278, artgallery.nsw.gov.au. 
LOOKING AHEAD NEXT WEEK With Halloween nearing, Running Scared combines frights with fitness. Participants are encouraged to don a spooky costume to tackle an after-dark, eight-kilometre obstacle course filled with more than 100 actors working hard to make the night extra eerie.  Octoberober 31, Sydney International Regatta Centre, Old Castlereagh Road, Penrith, $95-$105, runningscared.com.au. 
NEXT MONTH Many evenings are already sold out to see Geoffrey Rush tackle the challenges of King Lear, however a few seats still remain. Rush is directed by long-time collaborator Neil Armfield and appears alongside a talented cast including Robyn Nevin and Max Cullen.  November 24 to January 9, Roslyn Packer Theatre, 22 Hickson Road, Walsh Bay, $93-$120, 9250 1777, sydneytheatre.com.au .
STAYING IN  Leo Tolstoy's Anna Karenina gets a contemporary Australian retelling for the six-part drama series The Beautiful Lie . Star-on-the-rise Sarah Snook appears as a retired tennis champion who feels an instant attraction to a music producer, despite both already being romantically entangled. Tonight, 8.30pm on ABC.
